Award.AwardTitle: Investigating the Emergence of Cranial Modification and Violence among the Chanka of Andahuaylas, Peru (AD 1000-1400)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Under the supervision of Dr. Tiffiny Tung, Danielle Kurin will conduct the final phase of dissertation research using AMS radiocarbon dates to determine the chronology of several different mortuary contexts and associated human remains from prehistoric Andean populations, known as the Chanka. The research is focused on how the collapse of the Wari Empire structured violence and bodily expressions of ethnic identity among post-Wari Chanka populations, and the carbon-14 dates will enable Ms. Kurin to document the timing of serious outbreaks of violence, whether during the Wari era (MH, ca. 600-1000 AD), or in the aftermath of imperial collapse (LIP, ca. AD 1000-1400). The carbon-14 dates will also aid in determining when a practice known as cranial modification became a common means for signaling ethnic identity.

State collapse often causes people to redefine who they are, and how they interact with others. It is a recurring phenomeneon neither limited to a certain part of the world, nor a particular era in history. This research utilizes an innovative approach that elucidates mechanisms for violence and identity-marking applicable in both modern and ancient contexts of state disintegration. By documenting the emergence of violence in post-imperial populations like the Chanka, it may be possible to offer insights into the nature Wari fragmentation, specifically, as well as address broader issues of state transformation in general. This project provides a glimpse of a less-studied society and less-known time period, enriching and refining the chronology and history of the south-central highland Andes in general, and Andahuaylas in particular.

Human skeletal remains from imperial and post-imperial burials in Andahuaylas, Peru, were excavated by the Ms. Kurin; analysis revealed evidence for violence (inferred through skull fractures), as well as prominent, corporeal markers of ethnic identity (i.e., cranial modification). Based on associated ceramics, evidence from human remains appears to demonstrate an increase in violence following Wari imperial collapse. Importantly, cranial fractures are almost exclusively present on skulls that exhibit cranial modification, while unmodified skulls largely lack evidence of injury. Radiocarbon dates will be used in this final phase to test whether modified and unmodified individuals existed contemporaneously, or whether these individuals lived in distinct time periods. This final set of data is necessary to understand how Wari's decline may have restructured interactions between 'post-collapse' Chanka groups in the hinterland region of Andahuaylas, Peru.


The proposed research will have significant broader impacts. Project data formed the basis of two university courses developed and taught by the Ms. Kurin in Peru; artifacts and remains recovered during excavations will be exhibited at a new community museum in Andahuaylas, opened in late 2009 by Ms. Kurin and Peruvian colleagues. Future research in the region will continue to include female, minority, and indigenous students from both the United States and Peru. Finally, this project will result in Spanish and English language scholarly and general public publications, conference papers, and undergraduate and graduate theses, including Ms. Kurin's doctoral dissertation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of this project was to use bioarchaeological and radiometric methods to determine whether ethnic violence increased after the collapse of the ancient Wari Empire (AD 600-1000). Human skulls from south-central Peru were evaluated for evidence of head wounds (indicative of violence). Radiometric dating was used to date remains to  the Wari and post-Wari (AD 1000-1250) era. These results were used to better understand the bio-social impacts of state fragmentation.

During the project, we completed skeletal anaysis of 477 archaeological individuals, Completed radiometric dating of 16 samples of organic material, and organized a conference, edited volume, museum exhibits, and university curricula.

Our research demonstrates a couple of key findings: 1) violence increased significantly following the collapse of the Wari Empire ca. AD 1000; 2) Wari's imperial collapse spurred the creation of new ethnic groups in Andahuaylas between ca. AD 1000-1250; and 3) these new ethnic groups were singled out for deadly attack.

These findings are significant with respect to intelectual merits, because state collapse (also termed "state failure") is an ongoing phenomemon today. This research demonstrates that although violence is associated with the break-down of a state, conflict does not impact everyone equally. Rather, coalitions based on ethnic identity tend to form after a state collapse, and it is those novel ethnic groupings that are often targeted for violence. The same social patterns which existed almost 1,000 years ago in ancient Peru are visible today to some extent in politically unstable regions of North Africa and the Middle East. Furthermore, this research has helped us better understand the history of the south-central Andes, a region that witnessed te rise and fall of several major empires (Wari, Tiwanaku, and Inca). 

The research also had broader impacts. During the course of the project, the Co-PI trained and advised Peruvan students; American undergraduate and graduate students also recieved mentorship, training, and advising.  Underrepresented groups (women, minority, low SES, indigenous, LGBT) were included in all phases of research, and recieved substantial mentorship and advising. Fourty-seven American students and a dozen Peruvian students participated on the project. These collaborations have so far resulted in 2 Bch. theses, 4 Lic. theses, 10 BA theses, 2 MA theses, and 2 PhD dissertations, along with 25 co-authored professional papers and posters.

Project results were disseminated in museum exhibits which were created by the Co-PI at the Andahuaylas Museum (~10,000 visitors per year). The museum was featured on several nationally-aired documentaries (and now available on YouTube). The Co-PI and her Peruvian colleagues also organized a 2-day research symposium at the local university (Universidad Nacional Jose Maria Arguedas). The event, held in July, 2013, showcased project results related to skeletal analysis, artifactual analysis, biogeochemistry, and ethnohistory. The Co-PI also organized a Spanish - language edited volume of research reports by scholars working in the borader region (south-central Peru). In addition, the Co-PI designed and taught three courses (sociology [anthropology], research methods, and  field methods) at the local university (JM Arguedas). Finally, our ever-increasing photo data base and artifact/bone inventory have been used by several dozen young American and Peruvian scholars.
